We prove that being Fréchet differentiable at a point implies being Gâteaux differentiable at the point, and that in this case the Gâteaux derivative is equal to the Fréchet derivative.

(D * f * gamma * (t + h) - D * f * gamma * t) * (v - u)

para.p: and hence

Math.text: norm@(D * (f compose gamma) * (t + h) - D * (f compose gamma) * t) less= norm@(D * f * gamma * (t + h) - D * f * gamma * t) * norm@(v - u)

para.p:
Because
:
⁢ D f
→ U
⁢ B
( X , Y )
is continuous, it follows that

Math.text: norm@(D * (f compose gamma) * (t + h) - D * (f compose gamma) * t) to 0

para.p:
as
→ h 0
, i.e. that
⁢ D
(
∘ f γ
)
is continuous at
t
, and thus that

Math.text: D * (f compose gamma) colon I to B * open-interval@(R, Y)

para.p:
is continuous. If we identify
⁢ B
( R , Y )
with
Y
, then

Math.text: D * (f compose gamma) colon I to Y

para.p: On the one hand,

Math.text: ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(D * (f compose gamma)) = (f compose gamma) * 1 - (f compose gamma) * 0 = f * v - f * u

para.p: On the other hand,

Math.text: ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(D * (f compose gamma)) = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(D * f * gamma * t * (v - u) * differential-d@(t)) = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(D * f * ((1 - t) * u + t * v) * differential-d@(t)) * (v - u)

para.p: here,

Math.text: ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(D * f * ((1 - t) * u + t * v) * differential-d@(t)) element-of B * open-interval@(X, Y)

para.p: Therefore

Math.text: f * v - f * u = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(D * f * ((1 - t) * u + t * v) * differential-d@(t)) * (v - u)
